cmd.cites.cmd.second.line.cite: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information § 3:11

prop.head.headtext: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information

para.paratext: When information is available from other sources, the test seems to be whether a defendant would have been able to get to the developmental point it reached, within the same time frame, without access to confidential information. Subject to not breaching other intellectual property rights, it is clear that individuals and organizations will usually be free to use ideas developed by imitation or reverse engineering.

In the often cited case of Molnar Lithographic Supplies Ltd. v. Sikatory,[1] the trial court, relying primarily on R.L. Crain Ltd. v. Ashton,[2] held that, on the evidence, the plaintiff company failed to establish that a former employee had obtained knowledge of the ingredients of a formula from his former employer. By trial and error, using various trade publications and books (i.e., publicly available information), the former employee had developed a similar formula on his own. In any event, the evidence did not establish that the formula was a trade secret capable of protection.
The Ontario Court of Appeal dismissed an appeal by the plaintiff, Molnar, relying heavily on the determination of the facts by the trial judge, which were summarized as follows:

That the plaintiff had not, in his opinion, discharged the burden of showing that the formula in question was in fact a trade secret. He found on the evidence that neither Molnar, nor the defendant had any special knowledge of lithographing formulae but that both, using books and the assistance of a chemist, and by trial and error in the way of experimentation had produced an adequate product.
He also held that there was no evidence to satisfy his mind that the alleged trade secret was unknown to others.
He further stated in his reasons [at p. 201]:

“I am satisfied that the defendant used only his ordinary working knowledge in developing this formula. I am further satisfied that the solutions of both the plaintiff and the defendant contain a formula that is available to anyone wishing to acquire the same from books and experimentation.”[3]

Similarly, in MD Management Ltd. v. Dhut,[4] the court held that although the former employee could not take unlisted telephone numbers and addresses, he was not prevented form reconstructing contact information using publicly available information. However, it is equally clear that even where reverse engineering is possible, confidential information will still be protected: see generally, the Supreme Court of Canada decision in Cadbury Schweppes Inc. v. FBI Foods Ltd.[5]

An application to amend a statement of claim to add a claim against Graf, an employee of the corporate defendant, to claim damages of $7 million for a breach of confidence and copyright infringement was allowed in Resource Well Completion Technologies Inc. v. Canuck Completions Ltd.[6]

Resource supplied Canuck with Resource's down hole completion fracturing tools for use in fracturing horizontal wells. Resource claimed that the equipment was unique in both exterior and interior appearance and that the information relating to the components of its equipment was confidential and subject to copyright. Graf was hired in October 2011 as the engineering manager for Canuck. Emails between two senior officers of Canuck arguably indicated a plan to reverse engineer Resource's equipment with a hoped-for completion date at the end of 2011. Subsequently, Canuck manufactured the same kind of fracking equipment, which, from an exterior view, apparently looked identical to that of Resource's. In promoting its new equipment, Canuck allegedly used exact wording, images and photos of the equipment found in Resource's promotional material. In the fall of 2012, in an article in the magazine, Business in Calgary, Graf described the new Canuck equipment and its design advantages. Graf was hired for his expertise and experience as a professional engineer. He was to design and develop Canuck's equipment. Graf did not have access to drawings or models of the Resource equipment.[7]

The proposed amended statement of claim alleged that Graf, alone or with the other individual defendants, caused Canuck to breach confidence, pass off and infringe copyright. It is also alleged that he acted independently in relation to a claim for a breach of confidence and a breach of copyright. In other words, he reverse engineered the equipment himself.[8] If these allegations were true, one of three scenarios appeared possible:

1. Mr. Graf did so at the request of his employer and it is arguable, in line with the case law, that this act was so egregious, i.e. tantamount to theft, that it should attract personal liability. Arguably, an employee cannot undertake such acts and claim immunity on the basis that it was in the course of his employment.

2. He alone, or in concert with others, caused the corporation to do these acts, and they were not in the best interests of the corporation, as a corporation's best interests involve acting in a bona fide way, with the result that, arguably, he should be personally liable.

3. He did so unbeknownst to his employer, who hired him to develop the equipment, not steal the design from a competitor, and it can be argued, in line with the case law, that his acts take on the independence necessary to find him personally liable.[9]

The result was that, at this stage of the proceedings, it could not be said that the claim against Mr. Graf was hopeless. The evidence was modest, but certainly sufficient to support the allegation that Graf reverse engineered the equipment leading to the above described possible scenarios. It was not necessary at this stage to provide evidence establishing which scenario was correct. A consideration of the claim for a breach of confidence and infringement of copyright leads to the same result. There was sufficient evidence to allow the amendments and the law does not lead to the inevitable conclusion that the case was hopeless.[10]

Graf also argued that the evidence did not establish the criteria necessary to claim a breach of confidential information, i.e., that the information was confidential, and that it was communicated in confidence, and that it was misused to the detriment of the confider. However, the court observed that the motion before the court was not an application for summary dismissal of the claim.[11]
